text:
Yes! He is an amazing teacher and def got a lot of good advice from him. Lols he tells us thou that were his last class for awhile so he can build his YouTube channel. There is some great stuff he’s posted already too. 

I’ve meet on or two but generally I’m just taking the individual classes for Houdini. I originally came from Otis and have stronger ties with my friends from their. Most are working over at Cosa as Lighters and Animators. One of the reasons I’d like to get into vfx is so I can work with them, because I really enjoy working with close people. My job currently is more closed off in a sense so like to make the switch soon. 

Yea I was thinking of including maybe a blog section of some kind that way it be getting in the habit of adding updates on just learning materials. 

Lols real time-fx is really interesting in which the number one thing I’ve found in video games is how to cheat the look of everything. Unreal is def. great with its lighting and friendly artist tools for shaders/material setups. Unity is great tool and they just introduced their shader/material graphs like Unreal last year. I feel in game engines the biggest techniques to real time fx tends to be animating shaders and help geometry. 

Generally <http://realtimevfx.com|realtimevfx.com> is the place to go, but personally looking at old school video game break downs tend to show off how to get away with a lot of things. Also a lot of indie developers post stuff up on their twitter on their vfx development too. 

Lols so if you play a lot of video games looking at devs blogs usually tend to show off how the were able to fake things cuz everything in real time revolves around frame rates/ optimizations. 

Hopefully I can make a better list sometime this week for you. What kind of resources have you found so far for real time vfx? Also have you thought about looking into Houdini as well? Cuz I know Houdini’s platform in making tools for procedural modeling is def a standard for game devs. Which is funny cuz as much as I’d like to work towards that for games it’s a whole separate zone.  

Ohhhhhhh there’s a realllly good GDC talk about this I thought was really good in terms of Houdini pipeline for Game dev. Also if you follow the guys twitter it has a lot of cool vfx things he did with Houdini and how he used it in unity. <https://vimeo.com/326563304> 
<https://80.lv/articles/006sdf-developing-an-indie-adventure-platformer/amp/?__twitter_impression=true>

attachments.title: Simplifying Indie GameDev Workflows | Luis Garcia | GDC 2019
attachments.text:
Learn how speed up your 3D workflows while maintaining asset quality, build large scenes, or achieve a high number of asset variations.

In this session, Luiz show you how to get the most from Houdini Engine in your game development, and how to speed up repetitive tasks by creating Digital Assets that integrate directly into the game engine as fully functional assets.

More SideFX GDC Talks: 

Luis Garcia started his career as an artist then evolved into a generalist Indie Game Developer working on Suki & the Shadow Klaw with knowledge going from 3D Modeling to animation, C#, and shader scripting, counting with two unity certifications. Founder of Feline Arts, an indie game studio based in Mexico, a 3D adventure / platformer for PS4, Xbox One, and PC where Houdini has been one of the core tools used for the development of this project.

attachments.title: Building an Indie Adventure with Houdini | 80lvl
attachments.text: Lune from Feline Arts shared the details behind the development of Suki and the Shadow Klaw: pipeline, character and asset workflows VFX, camera work, and more.
attachments.fallback: Building an Indie Adventure with Houdini | 80lvl

text: Ohhhhh I’m not sureeee I’d unreal still has it in their store,but they have all the vfx spells they used in their blade and soul mobile game you could download for free and deconstruct how they pulled it off too

The one thing I def see is that in real time is the use of particles is very very limited. Generally it’s some for of moving shader with geometry that has moving vertices to create effects with. So like say a tornado is some swirling shader animation is the UV coordinates and place it on a deforming cylinder. To get the extra “layers” of clouds it be more cylinders cut into sections that deform and have a shader with opacities in them to appear thicker
Like for the game Outerwilds I worked on it was just a cylinder as the base and the tops parts are larger shorter cylinders on the top
